description: Nikola Petrak receives an urgent Directorate demand for authorization to deploy security forces and suppress unauthorized citizen gatherings and data networks. After a brief deliberation, Nikola approves the crackdown, citing immediate system stability concerns.

Security operations are mobilized across affected districts. Patrols target assembly sites and seize equipment from makeshift citizen data hubs. Residents respond with confusion and scattered resistance.
Directorate technicians trigger a controlled BCI 'degradation protocol,' shutting down core functions stepwise in hopes of regaining oversight as public systems falter.

Rada and networked activists uncover signs of orchestrated BCI failure. They collaborate to quickly back up resident BCI data and launch citizen-run alternative scoring systems to maintain basic civic access.

With the official BCI faltering, shadow BCI networks grow citywide. Openly run by citizens, these alternatives attract rapid migration, exposing past abuses and sparking debate between Council factions and the public over the legitimacy of both systems.
